questions.text:
A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department for progressively worsening abdominal pain. The pain started 2 weeks ago and is localized to the right upper quadrant. He feels sick and fatigued. He also reports breathlessness when climbing the stairs to his first-floor apartment. He is a retired painter. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms consistently. He began having sexual relations with his most recent partner 2 months ago. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin and enalapril. He is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 110 kg (264 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jaundice, a distended abdomen, and tender hepatomegaly. There is no jugular venous distention. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the right upper sternal border. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
18.9 g/dL


Aspartate aminotransferase
450 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase
335 U/L


Total bilirubin
2.1 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute viral hepatitis can manifest with a 2-week history of fatigue, tender hepatomegaly, and jaundice. Although unprotected intercourse with multiple partners is a risk factor for contracting hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection, the rise in transaminase levels in acute viral hepatitis would be more pronounced (typically > 1000 U/L) with ALT levels being higher than AST levels. Moreover, clinical features such as ascites and dyspnea would not be expected with acute viral hepatitis. Instead, a history of fever, nausea, and/or vomiting is usually present.

Cirrhosis in a patient with chronic liver disease due to HBV or HCV can manifest with ascites. In a patient with cirrhosis, however, liver transaminase levels are typically normal or only mildly increased, and tender hepatomegaly is not expected. Moreover, patients with cirrhosis are usually anemic, not polycythemic.

B) INCORRECT:

Pathologically increased intestinal iron absorption is seen in hereditary hemochromatosis (HH), which can manifest with diabetes mellitus, as well as features of heart failure (due to restrictive cardiomyopathy) such as dyspnea, fatigue, ascites, jaundice, elevated transaminase levels, and tender hepatomegaly. However, the onset of symptoms in HH usually occurs before the age of 60 years and patients with heart failure due to restrictive cardiomyopathy usually have other symptoms such as increased jugular venous pressure, pedal/sacral edema, and S4 on auscultation. Moreover, other features characteristic of HH (e.g., hyperpigmentation, arthralgia) have not been reported in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Thrombosis of the hepatic vein and/or inferior vena cava (IVC), which is typically associated with hypercoagulable states (e.g., polycythemia, thrombocytosis, pregnancy), is the most common cause of BCS. Obstruction of the hepatic veins reduces blood outflow and leads to hepatic venous congestion, ultimately resulting in congestive hepatopathy. Individuals with BCS may also present with signs of increased perfusion of portocaval anastomoses (e.g., esophageal varices or caput medusae).

The next best step in this patient is abdominal ultrasonography with a Doppler study, which is likely to show decreased or absent flow in the hepatic veins and/or IVC. If ultrasonography is inconclusive, CT or MR angiography should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of BCS. This patient should initially receive anticoagulant therapy. In addition, most patients with BCS require localized thrombolysis or balloon angioplasty and stenting. If symptoms persist, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) should be performed. If TIPS fails to improve the patient's condition, or if fulminant hepatic failure develops, liver transplantation is required.
Image Description:

Budd-Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow obstruction, most commonly caused by the occlusion or partial occlusion of at least two major hepatic veins (e.g., due to thrombosis).

The subsequent hepatic venous congestion leads to increased sinusoidal pressure, cellular hypoxia, and centrilobular necrosis, resulting in hepatomegaly and, eventually, a nutmeg liver.

D) INCORRECT:

Thickening and/or calcification of the pericardium is seen in constrictive pericarditis, which can manifest with fatigue, ascites, exertional dyspnea, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice, and elevated serum transaminase levels (due to congestive hepatopathy), as seen here. However, patients with constrictive pericarditis would also have increased jugular venous pressure, pedal/sacral edema, and/or a pericardial knock, and typically a predisposing factor such as cardiac surgery, chest wall irradiation, autoimmune disease, uremia, or a history of acute pericarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) can manifest with hepatomegaly and elevated transaminase levels. This patient's obesity and history of diabetes mellitus are also risk factors for NASH. However, the enlarged liver is usually nontender, and features such as dyspnea, lethargy, ascites, or jaundice are not expected in the absence of cirrhosis. Cirrhosis following NASH can cause ascites, dyspnea, lethargy, and jaundice; but in cases of cirrhosis, serum transaminase levels are typically normal or only mildly increased (due to depletion of hepatocytes), and patients are usually anemic, not polycythemic.
questions.hint: Elevated hemoglobin levels suggest polycythemia, which is an important risk factor for Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS), a condition characterized by progressive abdominal pain, jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, and elevated serum transaminases. Individuals with BCS may also develop ascites, which can cause abdominal distension and dyspnea. This patient's soft ejection systolic murmur is probably not diagnostically significant.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with hypertension comes to the emergency department because of progressively worsening abdominal pain that started 1 week ago. The pain is localized to the right upper quadrant. He has also noticed yellowing of his eyes and skin during this time period. Physical examination shows jaundice, a distended abdomen, and tender hepatomegaly. There is no jugular venous distention. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 19.2 g/dL, aspartate aminotransferase of 420 U/L, alanine aminotransferase of 318 U/L, and total bilirubin of 2.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute viral hepatitis can present with fatigue, tender hepatomegaly, and jaundice. However, the rise in transaminase levels in acute viral hepatitis would be more pronounced (typically > 1000 U/L) with ALT levels being higher than AST levels. Moreover, ascites, abdominal distention, and erythrocytosis would not be expected with acute viral hepatitis. Instead, a history of fever, nausea, and/or vomiting is usually present.

B) CORRECT:

Budd-Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic vein obstruction, which leads to hepatic venous congestion with subsequently increased sinusoidal pressure and cellular hypoxia. This results in liver cell damage that can lead to the development of a nutmeg liver and possible liver failure. Budd-Chiari syndrome is typically secondary to conditions involving hypercoagulable states, such as polycythemia vera (most common), pregnancy, or clotting disorders.
Image Description:

Budd-Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow obstruction, most commonly caused by the occlusion or partial occlusion of at least two major hepatic veins (e.g., due to thrombosis).

The subsequent hepatic venous congestion leads to increased sinusoidal pressure, cellular hypoxia, and centrilobular necrosis, resulting in hepatomegaly and, eventually, a nutmeg liver.

C) INCORRECT:

Thickening and/or calcification of the pericardium is seen in constrictive pericarditis, which can present with fatigue, ascites, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice, and elevated serum transaminase levels (due to congestive hepatopathy). However, patients with constrictive pericarditis would also have increased JVP, pedal/sacral edema, and/or a pericardial knock, none of which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Pathologically increased intestinal iron absorption is seen in hereditary hemochromatosis (HH), which can lead to liver cirrhosis. Although decompensated cirrhosis can present with fatigue, jaundice, and ascites without an increased JVP, the presentation is much more indolent than seen in this patient with symptoms starting 1 week ago. Additionally, erythrocytosis is not associated with HH, and tender hepatomegaly would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) can present with hepatomegaly and elevated transaminase levels. However, the enlarged liver is usually nontender and this patient's ascites, jaundice, and erythrocytosis would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's erythrocytosis is a risk factor for Budd-Chiari syndrome, which would present over the course of days to weeks with jaundice, ascites, tender hepatomegaly, and elevated serum transaminases without jugular venous distention.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department reporting 2 days of diffuse abdominal pain without nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. The pain is unrelated to eating meals.
On examination, she has a temperature of 37.1°C, a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 130/70 mm Hg. Her lungs are clear, and her heart rate and rhythm are regular. Her abdomen is moderately tender to palpation in the epigastrium, with mild guarding but no rebound tenderness or hepatosplenomegaly. She has no lower-extremity edema, and her neurologic examination is normal.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9700
4500–11,000


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
81
80–100


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
16.2
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
375,000
150,000–350,000


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
6.5
0.3–1.0


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
243
0–35


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
361
0–35


Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen reveals a hepatic-vein thrombosis.
What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome may lead to arterial or venous thromboses, but this condition is a less common cause of Budd-Chiari syndrome than myeloproliferative neoplasms are.

B) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria may lead to arterial or venous thromboses, but this condition is a less common cause of Budd-Chiari syndrome than myeloproliferative neoplasms are.

C) CORRECT:

Budd-Chiari syndrome results from obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. Myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) are the most common acquired risk factor for Budd-Chiari syndrome (seen in about 30% to 40% of affected patients), and polycythemia vera is the most frequent MPN associated with this syndrome. In some cases, the MPN-associated JAK2 V617F mutation is found in the absence of hematologic abnormalities at the time of the initial thrombotic event. However, patients with Budd-Chiari syndrome and the JAK2 V617F mutation are more likely to develop an MPN during follow-up than are patients without the mutation.

Key learning point: The most common risk factor for Budd-Chiari syndrome is the presence of a myeloproliferative neoplasm.

D) INCORRECT:

Use of oral contraceptives, especially estrogen-containing forms, increases the risk for thromboses, including those related to Budd-Chiari syndrome. The risk may be even higher in the setting of inherited thrombophilias (e.g., factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation G20210A). However, oral contraceptive use is not the most common cause of Budd-Chiari syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypercoagulable states are also associated with Budd-Chiari syndrome. Factor V Leiden is a common inherited thrombophilia mutation but is not specifically associated with intra-abdominal thromboses.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 63 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: hospital
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have a swollen, painful stomach.”
History of Present Illness:


2-month history of worsening abdominal distention

1-month history of abdominal pain and jaundice
has noticed prominent veins around the umbilicus

Past Medical History:

type 2 diabetes mellitus
rheumatoid arthritis

Medications:

metformin
glimepiride
hydroxychloroquine

Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

mother: deceased at age 43 from breast cancer
father: deceased at age 70 from prostate cancer 

Psychosocial History:

has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years

drinks a bottle of wine daily

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.8°C(98.2°F)
90/min
19/min
105/75 mm Hg
98%on RA
160 cm(5 ft 3 in)
55 kg(121 lb)
21.5 kg/m2




Appearance: not in distress
Skin: jaundice
Neck: no jugular venous distention

Abdominal: distended abdomen; right upper quadrant tenderness; caput medusae visible; liver span is 14 cm by percussion; shifting dullness present
Extremities: no edema or tenderness; femoral and dorsalis pedis pulses intact

Diagnostic Studies


Blood



 Hemoglobin
15.1 g/dL


 WBC
8,000/mm3



 Platelet 
174,000/mm3



 HbA1c
7.5 %


Serum



 Total protein
6.3 g/dL


 Albumin

5.4 g/dL


 AST
92 g/dL


 ALT
104 g/dL


 Total bilirubin
2.4 mg/dL


Peritoneal fluid



Color
Clear


Cell count
130/mm3



Total protein
3.7 g/dL


Albumin
2.9 g/dL


Glucose
90 mg/dL


Triglycerides
100 mg/dL



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has a family history of early-onset breast cancer, which increases their risk of developing ovarian malignancy. Ascites due to ovarian malignancy is typically the result of peritoneal tumor invasion and associated with a peritoneal fluid total protein concentration > 2.5 g/dL, but a SAAG < 1.1 g/dL would be expected. Ovarian malignancy will cause high SAAG ascites only if the patient has severe liver metastases. A different cause of ascites is much more likely in this patient with tender hepatomegaly.

B) CORRECT:

Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) manifests with jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes, and ascites due to portal hypertension. Ascitic fluid total protein levels are typically > 2.5 g/dL in early BCS. As liver damage progresses due to congestive hepatopathy, ascitic fluid total protein levels can decrease to < 2.5 g/dL, because hepatic sinusoid scarring prevents the passage of protein into ascitic fluid.
Image Description:

This illustration gives an overview of the differential diagnoses of ascitic fluid, based on appearance, SAAG, and ascitic fluid total protein. As illustrated, the ascitic fluid is usually obtained through a diagnostic paracentesis in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Note that while early Budd-Chiari syndrome will result in high ascitic protein levels, with progression to cirrhosis in late Budd-Chiari syndrome the ascitic protein levels decrease to < 2.5 g/dL.

LLQ: left lower quadrant; SAAG: serum-ascites albumin gradient

C) INCORRECT:

Cirrhosis due to primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) would cause features of portal hypertension such as ascites with a SAAG ≥ 1.1 g/dL. PBC is also more common in women aged 30–65 years and those with a history of other autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis. However, the ascites total protein level in patients with cirrhosis is < 2.5 g/dL.

D) INCORRECT:

Nephrotic syndrome may cause ascites due to hypoalbuminemia and decreased oncotic pressure. Type 2 diabetes mellitus and rheumatoid arthritis are risk factors for nephrotic syndrome, as diabetes mellitus may result in diabetic nephropathy and rheumatoid arthritis may lead to amyloid nephropathy. However, jaundice, hepatomegaly, caput medusae, and elevated liver enzymes are not expected in nephrotic syndrome. Moreover, in nephrotic syndrome, SAAG is typically < 1.1 g/dL and peritoneal total protein levels are < 2.5 g/dL.

E) INCORRECT:

Right heart failure due to constrictive pericarditis can cause tender hepatomegaly, ascites with a SAAG ≥ 1.1 g/dL, and peritoneal total protein levels > 2.5 g/dL. However, jugular venous distention and lower extremity edema are expected in right heart failure. Chronic constrictive pericarditis can cause cardiac cirrhosis, but patients with cirrhosis typically have an ascitic total protein level < 2.5 g/dL.
questions.hint: This patient has features of ascites (e.g., abdominal distention, shifting dullness). A serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) of ≥ 1.1 g/dL (5.4 - 2.9 = 2.5 g/dL) and the finding of caput medusae indicate ascites due to portal hypertension.
